title: 114_hr529

The tax treatment of section 529 college savings plans changed in 2001, making qualified distributions tax-free. These plans help families save for college, with 11.83 million accounts totaling $244.5 billion in assets. States offer plans with low minimum contributions to encourage saving for college. The President's fiscal year 2016 Budget proposes raising taxes on future distributions from 529 college savings plans, which could discourage their use and lead to more student debt. The Act aims to strengthen and modernize 529 plans to better support students and families. The Act allows computer technology and equipment to be considered a qualified higher education expense for Section 529 accounts. This includes expenses for the purchase of computer equipment, software, and Internet access to be used primarily by the beneficiary during their enrollment at an eligible educational institution. The amendment applies to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2014. Additionally, the Act eliminates distribution aggregation requirements. SEC. 3. ELIMINATION OF DISTRIBUTION AGGREGATION REQUIREMENTS. Amends Section 529(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code by removing subparagraph (D). Effective for distributions after December 31, 2014. SEC. 4. RECONTRIBUTION OF REFUNDED AMOUNTS. The amendment allows beneficiaries to recontribute refunded qualified higher education expenses to a qualified tuition program within 60 days after the refund date, not exceeding the refunded amount. Effective for refunds after December 31, 2014. The transition rule allows for the recontribution of refunded higher education expenses within 60 days after the refund date, not exceeding the refunded amount. Effective for refunds after December 31, 2014. The transition rule allows recontribution of refunded higher education expenses within 60 days after the refund date. Effective for refunds after December 31, 2014. Passed the House of Representatives on February 25, 2015.
